notes.note:
Starting with Firefox 127, we're enabling a new anti-tracking feature in Nightly: [Bounce Tracking Protection][1]. This protection detects bounce trackers based on redirect behavior and periodically purges their cookies & site data to prevent tracking.


  [1]: https://groups.google.com/a/mozilla.org/g/dev-platform/c/M6erM0SjPTM

Starting with [Firefox for Android][1] 128, the new tab strip feature for tablets is available for testing in Nightly builds! This enhancement makes tab management more intuitive and efficient, providing a smoother browsing experience for devices in that form factor. Please share your feedback on Google Play and/or the [Mozilla Connect post][2] to help us improve it further.


  [1]: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.fenix
  [2]: https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/tablet-amp-mobile-ui-tab-bar-for-android/idi-p/333
Firefox now supports playback of protected content from streaming sites like Netflix while in Private Browsing mode.

Firefox now has a simpler and more unified dialog for clearing user data. In addition to streamlining data categories, the new dialog also provides insights into the site data size corresponding to the selected time range.
Microphone capture through getUserMedia on macOS will use system-provided voice processing when applicable for improved audio quality.
Firefox is now available in the Saraiki (skr) language.
Starting with Firefox 128, hovering the mouse over an unfocused tab will now display a visual preview of its contents in Nightly builds.

Deprecated support of HLS playlist support in [Firefox for Android][1]. 

  [1]: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.fenix
Firefox now supports rendering more `text/*` file types inline, rather than requiring them to be downloaded to be viewed.
Starting with Firefox 125, the `transition-behavior` CSS property is now supported in Nightly builds.

Starting with Firefox 125, Nightly builds will attempt to establish TLS connections using a hybrid post-quantum key agreement mechanism (X25519+Kyber768). This may result in slow TLS handshakes or failed connections on networks with TLS intercepting middleboxes. The feature can be disabled by setting the `security.tls.enable_kyber` preference to `false`.

Starting with Firefox 126, the [shape()][1] function on [clip-path][2] property is now supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#shape-function
  [2]: https://drafts.fxtf.org/css-masking-1/#the-clip-path

Starting with Firefox 126, the [shape()][1] function on [offset-path][2] property is supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#shape-function
  [2]: https://drafts.fxtf.org/motion-1/#offset-path-property

Starting with Firefox 126,  [interpolation][1] between [path()][2] function and [shape()][3] function is now supported in nightly builds.


  [1]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#interpolating-shape
  [2]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-1/#funcdef-basic-shape-path
  [3]: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-shapes-2/#funcdef-shape
Starting with Firefox 127, Nightly users now have the ability to translate selections of text from the right-click context menu, rather than only being able to translate the entire web page.

Starting with Firefox 127, the [relative color syntax][1] is supported in CSS color functions in Nightly builds. This allows to create colors based on other colors.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_colors/Relative_colors

Starting with Firefox 127, [`@starting-style`][1] is supported in Nightly builds. This `at-rule` allows to define styles that are applied to an element when it is first rendered, enabling transitions on elements that are added to the DOM or that have their display type changed from none to another value.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@starting-style

The [`setCodecPreferences`][1] method allows applications to disable the negotiation of specific codecs (including RTX/RED/FEC). It also allows an application to cause a remote peer to prefer the codec that appears first in the list for sending.


  [1]: https://www.w3.org/TR/webrtc/#dom-rtcrtptransceiver-setcodecpreferences

The Accept header for images and documents was [changed][1] to better align with the Fetch standard and other browsers.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/Content_negotiation/List_of_default_Accept_values

Firefox now supports `@property` and the [CSS properties-and-values API][1].


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/CSS_Properties_and_Values_API

Starting with Firefox 128, Firefox Nightly now has initial support for the [CHIPS (Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State)][1] standard.


  [1]: https://github.com/privacycg/CHIPS

[Resizeable ArrayBuffers][1] and [Growable SharedArrayBuffers][2] are now supported in SpiderMonkey. This allows the size of an ArrayBuffer to be changed without having to allocate a new buffer and copy data into it.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer/resize
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/SharedArrayBuffer/grow
Firefox now proxies DNS by default when using SOCKS v5, avoiding leaking DNS queries to the network when using SOCKS v5 proxies.

system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 10 or later

### Recommended Hardware
-  1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster compatible processor or System on a Chip (SoC)
-  1GB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  500MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.15 or later

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 or Apple silicon processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - glibc 2.17 or higher
    - GTK+ 3.14 or higher
    - libglib 2.42 or higher
    - libstdc++ 4.8.1 or higher
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - PulseAudio

Firefox Nightly gets updated every day and as a consequence, the release notes for the Nightly channel are updated continuously to reflect features that have reached sufficient maturity to benefit from community feedback and bug reports. 

**Warning: Features listed here may or may *not* make a final release of Firefox.**

In addition to these release notes, you can follow ongoing development on our [@FirefoxNightly][1] Twitter account, our  [@FirefoxNightly@mozilla.social][4] Mastodon account as well as read our [Nightly Blog][2].

You can interact with other Firefox Nightly users and give your feedback to Mozilla staff in the [Nightly Matrix room][3] on chat.mozilla.org.


  [1]: https://twitter.com/FirefoxNightly
  [2]: https://blog.nightly.mozilla.org
  [3]: https://chat.mozilla.org/?#/room/#nightly:mozilla.org
  [4]: https://mozilla.social/@FirefoxNightly
